title: 109_s2586
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minority Entrepreneurship and Innovation Pilot Program of 2006". The findings are outlined in Section 2. The 2005 ``State of Black America Report'' by the National Urban League highlights significant "equality gaps" between African Americans and Whites, including disparities in net worth and unemployment rates. African Americans represent 12.3% of the US population but only 4% of businesses, while Hispanic Americans make up 12.5% of the population but only 6% of businesses. Native Americans account for approximately 1% of the population. Entrepreneurship is vital for economic growth and viability in all communities, including minority-owned businesses. Revenue from minority-owned businesses increased by 22.5% between 1987 and 1997, with a 10% annual growth rate, and employment opportunities within these firms rose by 23%. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include the Administrator of the Small Business Administration, Hispanic serving institution, historically Black college and university, small business concern, small business development center, and Tribal College. The term "tribally controlled college or university" is defined in the Tribally Controlled College or University Assistance Act of 1978. MINORITY ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND INNOVATION GRANTS. The Administrator will provide grants to historically Black colleges, Tribal Colleges, and Hispanic serving institutions to establish entrepreneurship curriculum and small business development centers on campus. The curriculum must include training in business management, marketing, financial management, market analysis, innovation, and strategic planning. Each institution receiving a grant under this section must open a small business development center that provides studies, research, counseling, management training, technical assistance for international markets, and referral services for entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The grant promotes innovation, niche marketing, capacity building, international trade, and strategic planning for small business development. Grant limitations include a maximum of $1,000,000 per fiscal year for each institution of higher education, usage only for curriculum development and small business center organization, and exclusion of building expenses and unrelated costs. Authorization of $24,000,000 for fiscal years 2007 and 2008 for the grant program, with a report required annually on grant awards and usage. The Administrator shall report on grants awarded for entrepreneurship programs, small business development centers, and economic impact data. Funding for this section is limited to appropriated amounts.
